div.head: CHRISTMASTIDE
div.p: "Christmas comes but once a year, and when it comes it brings good cheer."

So runs the old couplet—and aa far as the first line is conoeruetl it ifl almost universally correct. But it fails to take into aooount such an exceptional state ot things as that to be found in this country Here we have a large Greek element, and while the Anglican Pro testant Church and the Latin Cburcbea gener ally celebrate the birth of Christ on December 2ôth, the Greek and Eastern Cburcbea defer their celebration till the 7th of January—the period of the Epiphany. Consequently we get in Egypt two Christinas Days in the year, ea* h observed by a large number of commercial. men . indeed, so large is the Greek community here that practioally busioeea is suspended in moat houses on the later as well as the earlier date What a boon would this be considered in the busy City of London — at least by the employés, for such a state of things would hardly commend itself to the beads of firms, so greatly would it interfere with business of all kinds in that world's centre.

It is interesting to study the early records of the obeervanoe of Christmas Day. In a previous Christmas article we showed that its origin was distinctly pagan and quite unoon uected with the birth of Jesus Christ Indeed many early writers hold that it was s special providence that appointed the birth of Christ to take place in the midst of pagan festivals. Menander gives a long account of them, and considers that a festival held on the shortest day-the winter solstice—presented the opportunity of a transition to the Christian point of view , Christ, the sun of the spiritual world, beiug compared with the sun ot the amtenal world. The comparison was carried still further, for as in the material world it is after dark ness has reached its highest point that the end of its domiuion is already near, and the light begins to acquire freeh powet, eo, too, in the spiritual world Christ, tbt spinteal eon, must appear to make an end of the kingdom of darkness But the date to be observed presented a difficulty, and while the Western Churches decided on the 25th December, the Eastern Cburcoes deferred it till the Epiphany. Heoce the difference of dates at the preeeot time. Christmas is a time when absent fneods claim a goodly share of our thooghta Coupled with these, no doubt, in the minds of many Englishmen resident in Egypt, is the regret that they cannot be in the old country "to put their leg* under the parental mahogany. ' and enjoy the roast beef of Old England, or the plump Norfolk turkey These art things that are perhaps not obtainable in this country But we would say to our young friends, Cheer up ' Cold storage has been introduced, and if you cannot feaston a good sirloin of8ootch beef, you may get that excellent subetitute, a joint of the rich meat that comes from all paru, North, Central, and South, of the Amenoau c ontinent and which loses so little of its flavour in the freeting process, that it is often enjoy ed »» much as, and eveo preferred before,— when the source from which it comes is not known the borne fed beef. And the children - (b e»s them ), what of them at Christmas time! A glance at the shop windows fully assures us that they are not forgotten. It is worth while to pay a visit to the bazaars and large drapery establishments if only to note the plethora of dolls, mechanical toys, and noveltiea of all descriptions that are offered to the purchasers O' presents for the little ones. The Christmas tree, too, is quite an institution in Egypt do we wish to "ooe and all, both great and small," a very Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year. Now a days it is the oustom to filter the wi»h to that for a Happy Christmas, and tak ing into consideration the very many cases where the season from various causes cannot be a merry one, the old wish often seems a mock ery. W scan wish everybody happiness from the bottom of our hearts The "good cheer" of Christmas is too well established a thing for the old customs ever to be broken The fashions may change and the Yule Log disappear, but never will Chnatmaatide oease to be associated with family reunions and general feasting. Of late years a growing tendeucy bas manifested itself to make the testi val a time for a more general lo>*enmg of the puræ strings than formerly That Christmas-time is the only period of the year that mauy open their hearts and their purees for the benefit of the poor is a sad reflection, and reminds us of so many people who only put OD religion with their dunday clothe»* and feel when they take them off that there is uo necessity to think about spiritual matters tor another six days. None the lees do we rejoice to see the movement extend year after year, and if the progress is slow we trust that it will be sure In the large cities of Cairo and Alexandria we have many destitute wanderers who will be glad to reoeive some of the good things of the season, and uo doubt the Rudolph and other Homas will receive au increase of support that will enable them to give the poor who apply to them a good Christmas meal

div.head: A Happy Christmas to all our Readers
The Moore Case
div.p: Yesterday the libel actions brought by Mr Moore against various Cairo papers were fixed for a special hearing on the 6th February.

div.head: The Egyptian Institute
div.p: There will be a meeting of the Institute on the 3th inst. at 5pm when Mr. Fourtan will make some observations on the Schizaster genus.

div.head: The Tourah Murders
div.p: The execution of Mohamed Osman Esau, who was convicted of the murder of two prisoners at Tourah in September last, took place this morning at 10 a.m.

div.head: St Andrew's Church Alexandria
div.p: There will be a special service in this Church on Christmas morning at 10.30 am. Friends and visitors are cordially invited.

div.head: Salvage Steamer
div.p: The Danish salvage steainer "Denmark" ar rived at Suez, and will be permanently station ed here in readiness to proceed to the Red Sea when required.

div.head: Nonconformity at Alexandria
div.p: The Wesleyan Church at Alexandria will hold a Christmas service to morrow morning at 10 o'clock in the Sailors and Soldiery Ing. titude. The Rev. W. Dicking, A.W CF, and friends will conduct the service

div.head: Archbishop of Sinal.
div.p: His Beatitude the Archbishop of Sinai, ar companied by the Hellenic ex Minister of Education, Mr. Papamichailopoulos, arrived at Suez this morning from Sinai by S.S "Mahal lah." and will proceed to Cairo in a day or two.

div.head: The "Mollopolis" Mall
div.p: The following are the hours at which correspondence for Europe per the S.S "Helio polis" must be posted at the GP. O, Alexandria on the 26th inst:-Ordinary corres pondence 11 a.m; registered 10 am Money orders 10 a.m.

div.head: Telephone Girls
div.p: The employment of young women for work on the telephone system at Alexandria by the Telepbone Company of Egypt has proved quite & success. Although this new departure is only of recent date, no less that fifty five girls are now employed at Alexandria.

div.head: Railway Station Burglaries
div.p: While investigations are still proceeding re garding the recent tbeit from the station inoney box at Heluan, yet another theft of the same nature bas occurred at the same place, the money box heing again brohen open Inst night and the sum of L E. 150 stolen.

div.head: Riberos' Cirous
div.p: For those wishing an amusing two hours' entertainment tomorrow we can thoroughly recommend the matinée which will take place at the above circus. Several new items have been added to the original programme and the performance is quite worthy of patronage, The sensational bicycle feat "La piste de la mort' will form an item in tomorrow's programme

div.head: Theft of LE. 1000
div.p: The Vative Agriculturalists who had come up to Cairo from the provinces with the sun of LE 1000 for various business proposto in Cairo, were foolish enongh to leave it in at bag in the Hotel Moyad in the Sharia Ciot Bevi wbere they were staying, with the result that on their return from an excursion in the town the bag was found to have been robbed of its entire contents.
Egyptian State Railway Institute.

Save for the annual "Draw", the Egyptian State Railway Institute in somewhat quiet: during Christmastide, but with the Vew Year Bo greatly celebrated by Scotch folk, niti amonget the members there are many all in festive The programme arranged by the El tertainments Committee for New Year's Day will provide amusement for both me old. As usual the children are to be honom with a fete between the hours of 2 to 5 pm. with tbe band of the 6th Dragoons in atteod ance. An interval trom 5 30 pm to 6 30 pm allowed for tea, will be followed at 6 45 pm hy & grand concert. A fitting conclusion is a dance which is billed from 9.30 pm to 1.30 a.m. Admission is by invitation.

div.head: A Calro Wedding
div.p: A pretty wedding was celebrated in the presence of a large number of friends, by the Rev. J. Hilton Molesworth, MA at All Saints Church last Saturday morning, the contract ing parties being Arthur Dennis Lonche, of the Egyptian State Telegraph Department, and Ellen Perrott. The bride, who wore a lovely dress of white silk and carried a pretty bou. quet of white robes and lilies, was attended by Mrs. Caides (sister as bridesmaid and was given away by Mr. J. Perrott (uncle). Mr. Cook, of the State Telegraph Department, sup ported the bridegroom as "best man." Are ception was subseynently held at the residence of Mrs Caines and was attended by a large number of friends and officials of the Railway and Telegraphs Department The presents, which were of a most useful nature, were ny merous and costly

div.head: RELIEF OF LUCKNOW
div.p: COMMEMORATIVE DINNER
(Gazette's Special Service)
London, Monday

The Indian mutiny commemoration dinner of veterans is being held at the Albert Hall to day. the anniversary of the relief of Lucknow. The decorations are magnificent and special trains are being run from all parts of England 6(A) dinners and 664 hampers have lieen des patched to the absent veterans. Lord Roberts will preside. The organisation of the dinner is due to the "Daily Telegraph".
London, Tuesday

The Indian mutiny dinner was a great success. The King's message, expressing the ap preciation of the Empire for the conspicuous services rendered under trying circumstances and with gallantry and endurance which were the means, under Providence, of saving the Indian Empire from peril, was enthusiastically received

div.head: MEETING OF PARLIAMENT
div.p: London, Monday
Parliament will reassemble on the 29th of January.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive has ordered a six wheel automobile of 80-horse power for trips in the Marient district. The firm of Lorrain Dietrich will make it.

div.head: THE PERSIAN SITUATION
div.p: THE SHAH'S INTENTIONS
(Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Monday

The "Times correspondent at Teheran states that the Shah lias signed a declaration which has l«eu sent to assembly to mark the renewal of the fidelity of the Constitution. The Shah has accepted the condiboo* of the Meglise, including the punishment of the ringleaders of the riots end the dissolution of the court clique. The Shall received thé British end Rusrtian representative» and gave as»u ranees that he did noteutertain any intention A abolishing the constitutional regime.

div.head: EGYPTIAN CONSTRUCTIONS
div.p: TERMS OF RESALES

In further reference to the extraordinary meeting of the Egyptian Construction* which was held ou Sat unlay, we art now fa position to publish further details of the terms of sale etc on which the various branche* of the company are to be liauded over to their original owners

The McClure and Dorliug branch having suffered severely through scarcity of capital, the amount of £17,600 charged as goodwill must in consoqueuce be considered as a dead loss The term» of withdrawal are as follow» — The company take* 2,500 shares paid as part of the purchase price for Mr Dorling's Hbareof goodwill, Mr Dorling take» over the stock in respect of which, through depreciation of giKsiwill tbecompauy bears a loss of £8,800, the company keeps the book omets and lia- bilities of the branch and Mr Dorling relin- quishes all his rights to the directorship and other benefits of the contract of February 1906.

According to the director*, the Grant, Bondi and Chinn branch would, on an adequate capital, have shewn excellent result», but the company not having sufficient means at its disposal for working capital, or to meet it» engagements with the manager, they have arranged with the firm of Grant, Bondi and Chinn who repurchase their busiue*» as a going concern and will also return to the com pany the 10 000 «hare» paid for good will, forfeiting at the same time the bill for £6,679, part of the purchase price of the branch stock maturing ou the 1st April 1908 and paying to the company the sum of £9,100 in cash.

The retiring firm will also pay the amounts owing by their branch to the head uffice, and other branches of the company, amounting to about £5,000, Mr. Bondi to remain as manag mg director, while his company forego their share in the profits mal* tor the Construction* hy this branch during the past year, which profits amount to £2,200 also agreeing to forego their claim in arbitration for £4,000 on shares.

With reference to the G Boyes branch, the company retain laud at Rod el Farag included in the original purchase price, receiving from Mr Roves the sura of £4,000, value of stock, furniture fixings etc, the company is keeping the existing assets and liabilities of the branch and loses £880or the sale.

The land at Rod el Farag was purchased with a view of erecting larger maun tact unng work* as well as general depot for stock etc in order to centralize the business and reduce the working expenses, but in view of the present state of finances they propose selling this land at the first favourable opportunity, at an estimated depreciation of £9,000 The loss on the building contract at San Stefano amount* to £1895, due to tbe injudi cious technical supervision , the company adds that this loss brought about tbe retirement of the technical superviser» at the tenmnation of the work

An estimate of 10 has been allowed for on outstanding debts, as an allowance for tbe possible failures of various debtors to meet liabilities in view of tbe financial crisis. The sum of £11.897 under the bead of preliminary expenses has been written ofl, as it was felt that the gradual extention of this sum would reuder the payments of dividends impossible for years
The value of the company s stock as distinct from the branches is £1,695, this after allowing for dead loss on cement which suffered from climatic conditions.

div.head: DISCOVERIES IN EGYPT
div.p: Among a number ot occasional lectures that have lately been given at the Cambridge Union, may be mentioned one by Dr. Grenfell on the fragment of a Greek history lately discovered in Egypt. This narrative, unknown to n* More, was obviously a continuation of Thucy dides. Were the whole of it extant oui knew ledge of the early fourth century B.c. would take on a verv different form. Even the scanty relics are enough to anuul eight pages of Grote at a stroke and to blow much German Quellenkntik into this air Dr Grenfel in dines with Wilamowiti and others to assign the book to Theopompus hut from hisdeecrip tion it seems to contain but little of that edifving rhetonc and personal criticism which we have been taught to consider as "Echt Theopompisch" in later compilers

div.head: A CAIRO DIVORCE CASE
div.p: LADY VIVIAN AND MR. CURPHEY

We published a special telegram from London on Wednesday last announcing that Lord Vivian had obtained a divorce from his wife owing to her having committed adultery with Mr Alfred Curphey, th* well known Anglo Egyptian financier The case came be fore Mr Justice Bergrade last Tuesday. The detail* are as follows :—

His lordship gTSLted a decree nisi to the Right Hoo George C'reapigny Brabaion, Baron Vivian, on the ground of the misoooduot of his wife, Barbara (Neely, Ltd y Vivian, with the oo reepoodent, Mr Alfred Curphey There was no defense.

Mr. Rayford said Lord and Lady Vivian were married at St Michael'*, Pimlioo, in August* 1603, and lived at North Audley street. The married life for a time was a happy one There were two children In 1906 the petitioner went to Canada, and on his return, in October, oc d (ÿlrred the first real trouble, because be found a (hat hi* wife had arranged to take part in some theatricals at the Royalty Theatre He object ed, and finally per*uaded her to give up the idea

The following winter they arranged to go to Cairo, and then on a shooting expedition Be fore going, however, the petitioner spoke to his wife about tbe co respondent, whose acqu aintonce *he had made in Cairo Lord Vivian had got to know something about the oo respondent, and felt he was not a desirable person for hi* wife to know. The petitioner mentioned the matter to Lady Vivian before departing for the shoot in the neighbourhood of Khartoum On his ret urn to Cairo Lord Vivian found that his wife had made the aeqas in tance of tbe co respondent and some of the latter's friend*, to whom the petitioner strongly objected

Subsequently I^idy Vivian told her husband that she had arranged to go on a motor tour through France, but when he found that the co-respondent was to be one of the party he objected, and told the co respondent that Lady Vivian would not be one ot the party In the end there was no motor party, and the peti tioner and hi* wife retained home

The co-respondent and some of his friends shortly afterwards returned to England, and Lady Vivian was constantly going about to different places, and would have nothing to' do with her husband In tact (said counsel', from the time Lord Vivian returned from the shooting axpedition Iiady Vivian refused to live with him as hi* wife In Apnl last she left her husband s house, intimating that she would not return Lord Vivian had made every endeavour to get his wife to return *nd give up the co-respondent

On one occcasion Lord Vivian went and saw hi» wire at the Coburg Hotel, where she was staying, and promised to forgive her if she would return But she absolutely declined his offer, and left the hotel in a motor-car Sub- sequently, it was ascertained that she was constantly in the society of the oarespondent in the Isle of Man, and with whom she stayed at the Boston Hotel on the night of October 25 last.
Lord Vivian, in his evidence, corroborating counsel's statement, said that after the shoot ing expedition near Khsrtcnm his wife refused to live with him an his wife
His Lordship: What was the reason? — She refused, saying she did not wish it.
His lordship inquired who the co respondent wn*, and counsel said he believed him to lie a man of considerable wealth, who lived in the Isle of Man, and spent a great deal of his time at Cairo
Other evidence was called, and a decree nisi, with cost», and the custody ot the children was granted

div.head: ARRIVAL OF MAHMAL
div.p: A salute of 21 guns announced thi afternoon at 2 10 pm the arrival of the Mahmal special train at Suet, which attracted to the station thousands of natives, awaiting to see the disembarkment from the train Shortly after 3 30 p m the procession accompanied by the Governor of Suet, Bimbashi De Turris, chief of polio®, a military band, and detachments of infantry, artillery, cavalry and coast gnards, paraded through the principal streets of Snet, and presented a grand sight Toward* the evening the Mahmal was conveyed to the Suet Docks, and placed on board the Khédivial Moil liner "Minieh ", which will sail for Jeddah to-morrow

div.head: "BELOW THE CATARACTS"
div.p: This is the title of an exquisitely illustrated hook on the Nile Valley hy Walter Tyndall which wculd be an excellent choice for Christmas or New Year's present Tbe sixty coloured plates are as artistic as any similar representation» of modern and ancient Egypt that we have ever seen, and the letter press affords interesting reading Tbe author was the gueet of Mr George B Aldenon oo "Noah Ark" at Aboukir aod be gives a pleasant ao count of his «ojouro on that craft with his genial boat We are glad to note that tbe author promises another book dealing with Egypt above Thebe» We can heartily recommend this work to all residents in Egypt, ai it give* life-like picture of modern Cairo and tbe ruin* up the nver, and tbe general "g*t up'' of tbe work is in tbe higbeet degree artistic M Mr William Heinemann is the publisher

div.head: MIXED TRIBUNALS
div.p: MURDER OF VOLPINI

At the conclusion of the bearing of the first list of cases before the Mixed Court on Saturday Maitre Lusena rose amid silence to announce the sad loss the Egyptian Bar bas just sustain. ed by the terrible death of Maitre Volpini' at Alexandria and, expressing the general sympathy in a few well-chosen phrases, asked for an adjournment in token of respect. The President (Judge Tuek) after consulta tion with his colleagues acceded to the request speaking in similar terms, and the Court ao cordingly rose for a few minutes. On the resumption of the sitting certain applications in bankruptcy proceedings were heard and decided. The action brought by Altaras Silvera & Co. against Hadid Hanoui & Fuls was deferred for a fortnight to allow three necessary signatures to be affixed to the con cordat preventit lately entered into
LES FILS DE R. PICARD V. JACQUES MISRAHI AND OTHERS

This was a dispute concerning some goods parebased by the Defendants and sums of money alleged to be due therefor. Maitre Morpurgo for the Plaintiffs claimed payment of £E. 100 in lieu of the £E. 7.500 admitted by the Defendants. A safe sold to the latter by his clients, to be paid for in monthly ins. talmente, was still in the defendants' sbop, the Plaintiffs having been unable to remove it as the door was too narrow (Laughter). His clients were claiming the remaining instalident of the price of this safe. Maitre Nahas, who appeared for the Defendants, contended that the safe was an old one and that his clients were willing to pay what was just, adding that certain other goods belonging to the Defendants and beld "en dépôt" by the Plaintifts were amply sufficient to cover his clients indebtedness to M.M Picard. This Maitre Morpurgo disputed, pointing out that the pledges aforesaid had already been forfeited and sold by the buissier of the Court. Judgement was deferred for a week.
AHMED ALY EL DACROUR.

In the matter of the Concordat Preventif sought by the above named debtor, Maitre Terrante representing Messrs. Sebutz and Payer the principal creditors, alleged had faith on the part of the applicant, pointing out as a curious rirenmstance that the registers producel shered all the entries for two years past to have been written by the same hand, and | further complaining of the delay in putting in the account Maitre Biggiavi said bis client (the debtor) would require time to settle the account with Messrs. Schutz and Payer. Dacrour was ooly a small trader and, although not legally entitled to a concordat, his bills having been protested be appealed to the Court to sbew a little indulgence, as was usual both in Egypt and in Italy. Schutz, in fact, controlled the committee of creditors the other two members being his nominees. The registers would be seen to be genuine on inspection; their age was apparent. Moreover, be added, the bills produced did not correspond with the bankrupts' re gister, Schutz had only been a creditor since 1905.
CORRIER v. AUTO GARAGES AND AUTO-CABS CO.

This was an action for compensation by the Plaintiff who alleged that he had been dismissed from the Company's service with inadequate compensation. Maitre Manu sardi, for the Company,contended that the Plaintiff bad been fairly treated by his clients; and that, although he had given trouble in refusing to obey orders, and had cansed a strike of employés, the Company bad offered to retain him in its service on his signing a document and promising to conform, to its wishes in future. This he refused to do unless the manager were dismissed. So lately as last October the Company again offered to take back the Plaintiff if he would promise to obey orders as other employés did, especially with regard to the control of the entrance to the garage, in fact he was to con form to his original agreement of February 1905. Five days were allowed him in which to | reply, failing which he was taken to bave defi nitely resigned He therefore, said comsel, was only entitled to his salary for the three months ending on September 30. 1907, viz, L.E. 300, instead of the L.E. 500 now claimed. The work bad to be carried on somebow and accordingly his post had since been filled np. Maitre Oriel for the Plaintiff urged that the weakness of the Company's case was shown by the fact that Mr. Galli, a director, had in July (while the dispute was pending) offered Mr Corrier L.E. 20 out of his own pocket, in addition t L.E. 60 put forward by the Company as an indemnity. His client might bave been a little hasty in his language towards the Company, but certainly not impolite, as alleged. On October 30 he was ready to make reparation if the Defendants would take him back. Corrier bad resigned a good position in Paris to come to them, and had now lost 6 months' work and salary amounting to L E 120. He was justified in asking for a large indemnity since the 2 years' contract bad been broken. This closed the case, and judgment was deferred for a fortnight

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Lord and Lady Cromer left London on Sunday last to spend Christmas in Scotland.

His Highness Prince Mirza Riza Kben Arfa Bd Douleh, Persian Ambassador in Constantinople accompanied by his suite, arrived at Alexandria from Constantinople yesterday and has taken appartments at the Carlton Hotel, Ramleh.
Count Joseph de Sizzo Norris and Counters Sizzo Norris have transferred their quarters to the Carltoo Hotel, Ramleb.

Miralai Stack Bey, the private secretary to the Sirdar, will be transferred, says the "Sudan Titnes," to the Office of Sudan Agent, Cairo, to replace Miralai Owen Bey wbo has been ap pointed Governor of Mongalla Province. Kai makam Cameron Bey, Governor of Mongalla, is transferred to Kassela Province, 'in place of Wilkinson Bey whose transfer to Berber we re cently noted. We furtber learn that Kaim Clayton Bey will be appointed private secretary

An engagement is announced between Mr. Roland George Orred, Coldstream Guards, of Tranmere, Roncorn and Weston Cheshire, only son of the late Major Orred, 12th Royal Lancers, and Miss Cynthia Adela Victoria Pitz Clarence of 41, Ovington-Square, Bromp ton, S.W. Mr. Orred is at present with his regiment quartered at Abbassieh.
Bimbasbi R.A. Birley, of the artillery, is struck off the strength of the Egyptian Army.

Mrs. William Jennings Bryan, wife of the candidate for the Presidency of the United States is on her way to Egypt. She is accompanied by her daughter, Mrs. Ruth Bryaa Leavite. They will visit Palestine after Egypt.

The shareholders of the North Egypt Land Company, in liquidation, will be interested to learn that the Earl of Galloway, one of the original members of the board of directors of that unfortunate company, is selling 23,490 acres of his Wigtownshire Estates, an opset price of £487,000 is asked. Comprised in the estate is the barony of Baldoon, the house of the ancient family of Dunbar and celebrated as the last resting place of the "Bride of Lammermoor."

Lieut. G. A. Campbell of the Coldstream Guards wbose musical play "In Barcelona" may be remembered last season, is again buby preparing a pantomine for the forthcoming winter. This will be staged in all probability at the Abbas Theatre early in Pebruary and sbould prove & welcome addition to our calender of coming events. The proceeds will be devoted to various local charities.

div.head: ARMY NOTES
div.p: Captain D G. H. Avohinleck, Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, has been granted a two years' extension in the adjutancy of the 5th Battalion, Ballyshannon.

Captain Earle, Inniskilling Dragoons, the popular adjutant of the King's Colonials, has been granted an extension in that appointment at the urgent request of his Co., Colonel the Honourable H.A. Lawrence.
Captain Ovans, of the home battalion of the King's Owo Soottish Borderers, has been selected for the adjutancy of the 3rd Volunteer Battalion Highland Light Infantry.
The 2nd Battalion Connaught Rangers, which was serving some years ago in Egypt, will leave Bombay on the 6th March for home. It will be stationed at Tipperary.
The 3rd Battalion Royal Fusiliers, recently at Cairo, has moved from Middelburg to Pretoria.

div.head: TAXIMETERE CABS
div.p: The taximetre cab has come to Cairo. There are already two or three of these on the streets and very smart they look, the drivers seemingly taking a great pride in their singularity. W betber this pride will remain in the face of the losses they will suffer in the payment of ordinary fares by the gentle tourist remains to be seen, but any way there can be no doubt us to the appreciation extended to them by the public which has for so long been a viotim to the language and importunities of the cabby.

div.head: THE SEASON'S GREETINGS
div.p: Among the calendars and almanacks being sent out by firms for the New Year ve may mention those of Mr. N. Spathia, the wellknown mineral water manufacturer of Cairo, the Yorkshire Insurance Company, and of the Sun Pire Office. The Cleopatra Cigarette Co. is presenting an elegant blotting pad to its many clients. Nesens. Walker and Moimarachi are distributing bunebes of mistletoe and holly among their customers

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Moss liner "Seti" arrived a Liverpool on Sunday afternoon last the 22nd inst.

The principal objective of the operations now is Silwane's tribe, in the neighbourhood of Greytown, which is the most powerful in Natal. Silwane was loyal during the last rebellion, but is now suspected (Reuter)
The Natal troops are demobilising. Further operations bave been abandoned. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE PERSIAN CRISIS
SHAH AND PARLIAMENT

div.p: The Shah has sent Parliament a copy of the Koran with a signed and sealed declaration promising to observe the Constitution. He has agreed to the punisbment of the authors of the disorders and to the establishment of a per manent guard of the House of Parliamout, consisting of 200 infantry He also places all troops including the hitherto independent Cossack brigade, under the Ministry of War. Tbc shops have been reopened. (Reuter)

There is reason to believe that the negotiations between Japan and China regarding the telegraphs in South Manchuria art not of a discouraging nature. The complaints regarding incivility on the Manchuria railway are likely to be remedied now that a civil authority is taking it over. (Reuter)

Lord Kelvin was buried in Westminster Abbey. The ceremony was most impressive. The eminent scientists of Great Britain and the Continont, Ambassadors, the Lord Mayor, and delegations from Universities were present. The King and Prince of Wales were represented. (Reuter)
Three more bodies were recovered from the ruins yesterday, also a little four year old girl wbo was alive but unconscious. She is expected to recover. (Reuter)
The King, speaking to a journalist, eulogised Admiral Fournier. He expressed the opinion that small fleets would suffice for the detence of Greece. (Harus)
The explosion of a bomb in the street has killed a soldier (Haras)
Five workmen have been killed by the explosion of a caisson (Havas)
The American fleet has arrived. (Reuter)
The astronomer Janssen is dead (Reuter)
M.C.C. 503 runs for 9 wickets. Declared closed. Victorians 156 runs for 3 wickets. (Reuter)

div.head: PORT SAID AND CAIRO NAVIGATION COMPANY.
div.p: The company has been founded noder the auspices of the Petsaly Coal Company, which is well known as an importer of coal into Alex Andria. It is registered in accordance with English law, and has & capital of £20,000), divided into 4,000 shares of £5 each. Objects Transport by towing of coal and other mer chandise between Port Said and Cairo, either through the Suez Canal or the lsinailia fresh water canal. The advantages of this Lew route are numerous. There will be no trans shipment in regard to the land transport, and the Capital will thus be in direct cominunication by water with Port Said. Material required by the new company is now under construction in Eng land, and the new service will be inaugurated in April next. The rates of freight will be the sane as those now in force on the AlexandriaCairo line. Directors : Messrs A E. Bowen, J. I Whitehead, and S. Petsaly (the last-named being managing director) The offices of the company are in London (Salisbury House, London Wall), and it has branches at Port Said, Cairo, and Alexandria.

div.head: LAUNCH OF S.S. "LORD CROMER"
div.p: A NEW STERNWHEELER

A new stern wheel steamer, built by the Sudan Development and Bxploration Company, Limited to the order of the Repression of Slavery Department, was successfully launched on Saturday afternoon, the 14th. December, at the Company's Workshops, Khartoum North. Owing to the limited time at the disposal of the builders for the completion of the vessel, no othcial ceremony was arranged, as it was essential that the boat should take the water immediately the last rivet had been put in place At the request of Captain McMurdo, the Director of the Slave Trade Repressjon Depart ment,Mrs Asser, wife of the Adjutant. General, Egyptian Army, graciously performed the informal ceremony of christening the vessel. The following were also present ;-Colonel and Mrs. Hunter, Colonel Asser, Mr. and Mrs. More, Mr. and Mrs. Harcourt Paine, Mrs. Cross, Mr. Norman Wilkinson, Mr. Harold F. Hall, etc. | Five minutes after the arrival of this party trom Khartoum, Mrs. Asser severed the ribbon connecting the orthodox bottle of wine, and gave the vessel the name "LORD CROMER", which immediately took the water in record style. Great credit is due to Mr. Sharp, the com pany's foreman of works, and his staft for the admirable arrangement made for the launch, which was an unqualified success. This stern wheel steamer, from its graceful appearance, promises to eclipse any boat at present afloat south of Khartoum A speed of ten miles per hour is guaranteed by the buil ders, and they have every hope of exceeding this when the steam trials take place next month During the ceremony, the following telegram was received from Captain A. McMurdo :--- "'Thank Mrs. Asser for the houour she has done the department of christening the steamer which will help to perpetuate the memory of the great statesman after which the boat is named." In a few well chosen words from Mr. Wil kinson, who represented the Departinent, the success of the boat was proposed and the toast duly honoured Mr. Haruld F Hall, Manager of the Sudan Development and Exploration Company Limited, proposed a vote of thanks to Mrs. Asser and those present, which brought the proceedings to an end.

div.head: SUPREME CONSULAR COURT.
div.p: The Cairo Correspondent of the "Daily Telegraph," in discussing the number of cases Judge Cator had to judge, remarks that the recent sessions of the Supreme Consular Court "have once more brought to the foreground a very real necessity, namely, the residence in Egypt of a British judge, or the increasing of the powers of the mixed tribunal. For as the British community increases in size and in wealth, 90 do its legal necessities grow, and it is becoining more and more impossible to meet these necessities by ineans of a judge, however able he may be, whose place of resideboe in Constantinople, added to the fact that he is of necessity out of touch both the feelings and the needs of a community with which he so seldom comes in contact.

div.head: DISMISSED FROM HOSPITAL INCURABLE
div.p: TERRIBLE KIDNEY DISEASE FOLLOWS A CHILL

Mr. John McCrorie, 11, Preston Street, Govanhill, Glasgow, Scotland, gave an account of his illness to one of our representatives. He said My illness, which I trace to getting wet and cold, Coinmenced about November, 1901, with sharp, shooting pains in the small of iny back, het weep my shoulders, in my head. right side, and occasionally about my heart. 1 was also troubled with heallache, drowsiness, dimoess of sight, geeing spots before my eyes, sleeplessness, poor appetite, and general weak nese, which gradually grew worse and worse, About three weeks ofter my illness commenced iny face, hands, limbs and body began to swell, and at the same time I was attacked by urinary disorders which caused 19 ere pain. When I called the doctor in he informed me that I was suffering from a inost severe torin of kidney disease, after he bad trested me a short time he told me that he could do little for me and that I must go to the hospital. I went, and lay there for 14 weeks, but the treatment did me little good Eventually I was advised to leave the hospital as no more could be done for me. "I heard of Doan's Backache Kidney Pille and decided to give them a trial After taking them about three weeks I felt that tbey were doing me good, and from tben onward I grew better and stronger every day, so that I knew at last I had obtained a medicine which was aoting directly on my trouble. I kept on with the pills until I felt that I was the same man in health and strength that I had been betore my illness. Then, 4 years after his cure Mr. McCrorie said: "Since my cure I bave never had the least returi of my old trouble.' div.head: THE CRISIS IN EGYPT
div.p: ITS INFLUENCE IN STAMBOUL.

The financial crisis prevailing in Egypt appears to have had an effect in Constantinople, which has a crisis of its own. Renter's correspondent writes : The causes of the crisis are many and various, one factor being the tendency of bauks to give large eredit. The first setback which the local market experienced was the result of the orisis in Egypt. The Egyptian krach" greatly undermined the predit of Near Eastern business paper generally and especially in London. The local banks thereupon, began to insist on more cover, and, scared by the failure of one or two big Armenian firms, refused to show any indulgence, thus greatly accentuai ing the difficulties of their clients, npon whom they had previously pressed almost unlimited credit.

div.head: SAILORS' AND SOLDIERS' INSTITUTE
div.p: The Fancy Sale at this lostitute passed off very successfully. Apart from the two large | fancy stalls where many pretty and useful 1 articles were displayed, there was the great attraction of the Christmas tree for which many of the little folk impatiently waited. Mrs. Morrison, who had spent much time on the previous day in decorating the tree was unable to be present, but the Misses Davis sussisted by three or four gentlemen, most ably and quickly distributed the prizes to the satisfaction of all the little holders of tickets. Shortly before 4 o'clock the refreshment tables, over which Mrs. Algernon Ward presided, were all occupied, and by 5.30 o'clock 156 persons had partaken of an excellent tea. The ladies, who assisted Mrs. Algernon Ward, were the the Hon. Mrs Hopkinson, Mrs. Neville Borton, Mrs. Hicks Paull, Miss Garnett Botfield, and Miss Phyllis Mo88. Mrs. P. H. Kingham who presided at one of the fancy stalls was most successful and although most of the articles on this stall were trifles, at low prices, over £18, (including sale of tickets by Miss Gwendolen Kingham) were realized. Mrs. Benwell Rees and Mrs. Stanley Gordon, assisted by Miss Lang Anderson, Miss Gertrude Carver, ani Master Basil Rees, as usual, did a brisk trade, more than £22 being gained at this stall A pleasant afternoon was rendered still more enjoyable by the excellent music played by the string band of the 2nd Bat. Royal Inniskitling Fasiliers, kindly lent by the Colonel and officers of the regiment and most ably conducted by Mr. Watson Ramsey The following are the names of those who have kindly contributed articles to the taucy and refreshment stalls : --Mrs. Bavin, Mrs. Neville Borton, Mrs. Bachanan, Mrs. Percy Carver, Mrs. S. R. P. Lipton Ltd., Del Mar, Badour, Kurk and Walker & Meinarachi HE. Mustapha Pasha Ibadi sent L.I. 1. Mrs Geo. div.head: EGYPT AND THE ZOO
div.p: The fact of Lord Coomer being elected a Fellow of the Zoological Society is interesting because the rulers of this country with which he has so long been associated have contri buted many magnificent specimens of the fauna of that historie territory. The first giraffe ever brou ght alive to this country was that presented I to King George IV, by the Pasha of Egypt - Mohamed Al-while soon atter the foundation ot the society his Highness Ibrahim Pasha -Viceroy of Egypt - made an important contribution, consisting of a giraffe, two drome daries, four antelopes, two ostriches, and two gazelles. This was in 1849, and five years later the Pasha presentad & notable hippopotamus, the mother of the animal known familiarly as 'Guy Fawkes," which has been a resident in the gardens ever since the year 1872.

div.head: THE MAMELUKE MASSACRE
div.p: If writer in the "Spectator" declares that up Ito two years ago an old sheikh was living in Cuiry, who had witnessed the great massacre of the Mamelukes at the Citadel He writes :e Unul two years ago there was living an old 1Sheikh who ou state occasions sat at the chief estnance to the citadel, in a chair especially made for him, over which are written the words, in Arabic and English: "Only be, who by the favour of God, bas reached the age of a hundred years may sit in this chair." At his death in 1905 he was said to have been a hundred and fourteen, and on the only occasion, just four years ago, when I had the pleasure of speaking with him, he gave me a graphic description of the massacre of the Mamelukes, saying how "the blood poured down the steep pathway to the gate like a river of water." Even it he was ten years younger at his death than theage ascribed to him and in Egypt what native knows his age!), he might very easily have been old enough to remember the details. His father was, according to his story, "Bowab" or gate keeper of the citadel, and he himself was play. ing near the gate just as the Pasha was wreaking his vengeance on the unfortunate Mamelukes It is of course possible that frequent repetition had embroidered the original tale but in any case it is interesting to think that until such a short time ago there was one still living who was actually spectator of this scene.

div.head: ENGLISH COMPANIES IN EGYPT
div.p: THE QUESTION OF JURISDICTION.

Some of our readers have requested us to publish a summary of the arguments of Mr. Robert Devonshire, who represented the Bourse and Banking Company of Egypt before the Supreme Consular Court, where he contest ed the jurisdiction of the H. M's Consular Courts re an application by a shareholder for removal of the Liquidator appointed by the shareholders and for the appointment of another liquidator in his place. The following is a resumé ot Mr. Devonshire's arguments:On behalf of the liquidator it was argue on appeal to the Judge of the Supreme Consular Court that the Court has jurisdiction to en tertain this application. The bends of the argument are as follows: 1. L'nder the Companies' Act 1861 Section 141 "the Court" may on due cause shown remove any liquidator and appoint another • liquidator to act in the matter of a voluntary winding up. The Companies' Winding l'p Act 1890 Sec tion 32 defines the Court" As meaning the Court having Jurisdiction under that Act to wind up the Company 2. The only Courts having jurisdiction in England to wind up a Company are the High Court, the Chancery Courts of the County Palantine of Lancaster and Durham and the County Courts 3. The jurisdiction of the Supreme Consular Court is governed by the Order in Council 1899. Article 107 of this Order in Council Exvides that.

"the Supreme Court shall as far as cir"cumstances admit for and within the "Ottoman dominions with respect to "British subjects all such jurisdiction "'except the jurisdiction relative to diso "lution or pulity or jacuitation of marriage "as for the time being belongs to the High "Court in England."

The Circumstances do not adunit of the Bupreme Court having jurisdiction of the High Court with reference to the winding up of Coinpanies. The complicated procedure under the Companies Acts involving certain special powers given to the Board of Trade make it imposible in practice for the Consular Court to exercise the powers of the High Court. Article 167 of the Order in Council is as follows

"Where, by virtue of this order or "otherwise, any Imperial Act, or any Law "in force in a British Possession, Colony, "or Settlement is applicable in any place "within the limits of this Order, such • Act or Law shall be deemed applicable "so far only as the constitution and juris "diction of the Courts acting under this "Order and the local circunstances per "mit, and, for the purpose of facilitating "the application of any such Act or Law, it may be constructed with such alter "ation and adaptions not affectmg the "ubstance as may be necessary, and any "thing by such Act or Law required to be "done by or to any Court, Judge, officer or "authority may be done by or to a Court. "Judge, officer, or authority having the "like or analogous functions, or by or to "any officer designated by the Court for "that purpose, and the seal of the Court "Inay be snostituted for any seal required by any such Actor Law; and in base "any difficulty occurs in the application of "any such ct or Law, it shall be lawful "for the Secretary of State to direct by and to whom, and in what manner, any "thing to be done, and much Act or Law "shall, in its application to matters aris ing within the limits of this Orier, be *onstructed accordingly."

The Companies' Acts, so far as winding up is concerned, are not applicable in any place within the linits of the Order If and so far as they are applicable in theory the constitution and jurisdiction of the Con sular Court do not perinit of their application 5. Article 12 of the Owler in Council provides

"That as regards all such matters and "cases 18 cotne within the jurisdiction of "any Egyptian Courts established with the concurrence of His Majesty, the operation of the Order is suspended until His "Majesty by and with the advice of His "Privy Council sball otherwise under

The Mixed Tribunals are competent, in all cases where the Creditors of a company ate of mixed nationality, to protect the interestent the Creditors by declaring a Company in

solvent and by liquidating its affairs for the benefit of the Creditors, To sun np the arguments the Consular Court is incompetent by reason of the conflicting jurisdiction of the High Court in England and also by reason of the conflicting jorisdiction in Egypt Mr. Gooiling in replying for the respondent in this appeal made remarks to the following effect He felt sure that all who hart heard Mr. Devonshire were under an obli gation to him for his very interesting address to the Court on behalf of the appellant. The point, however, which had been raised by his learned friend dit not materially affect the case. On the one hand was a Company register ed under the Companies Acts 1862 1900 with an office registered in London to bring the Company within the jurisdiction f London and therefore a corporate body, an English body and on the other, was an Englishman who had brought this action on broad general principles, and in the interests of the public. | The powers of the London Courts had been conferred on the consular Courts of Egypt by the Orders in Cotineil known as "The Principal Order 1899" -- and he relied on that Order which had long guided the Consular Courts in dealing with these matters He said that the I point raised by Mr. Devonshire had been dealt with by the leamed judge whom he asked to do nothing at this junetore when the confidence of the publie was much shaken in directors of public companies, to interfere with or limit in any way the jurisdiction hitherto exercised by the Consular Courts of Egypt and to dismiss the appeal of the appellant company It was ordered That the appeal be dismissed with costs

div.head: CAIRO'S HOUSING PROBLEM
div.p: To the EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir, -In reply to "Interested'" lotter, it would serve no good or useful purpose after this lapse of time to attempt to dig out from the dusty arcbives of the past the difficulties confronting, or the objections put forward in the winter of 1891-1892 to the Government taking upon its shoulders the duties of landlord to its civil permanent staff; some of those objections and difficulties may no tonger exist, but be sure that either some old or new ones still be snay the Government path to a solution ; yet it is still open to Interested" or anyone else to make a further essay. Muebas I should like to, I feel I ought not to trespass on your space in detailing the various attempts made to obtain from home the financial sup port with which to establish a civil service cooperative society with which was to have been incorporated a building society based on the lines of the Birkbeek, Starr Bowkett and kindred institutions, but it "Luterested" chooses to make my personal acquaintance (I sball res. pect his desire to remain anonymous) I would give him an interesting resumé of these. I regret that I did not make it clearer that those I had in mind were the better class, well educated but poorly paid civil servants (and not the highly paid otheials) who have long yearned for a home which they might call their own, and from which they could not be turned out or bad their rents doubled at the whim of a capricious landlord. My suggestion is to commence by aiding those employés who some years since bought building sites of about 1,000 metres square each, at prices from LE. 10 to L E. 50 per plot. Compare these prices with those of the cheapest lands now obtainable On these 1,000 metre sites a good bun galow pattern house (six or 8 roomed with usual offioes) may be soustructed, Jearing say 600 square metres for kitchen and ornamental garden, poultry run, fruit trees etc. The size and therefore cost of each house would be governed by the requirements and means of families or individuals, but accept As a general average LE. 400 as the cost of the largest houses, the probable bighest monthly charge would be L E 4, viz : 7% interest and 5 amortization per annum. As a set off to this charge there would be taken into con sideration the economy resulting from the growing of ones own vegetables and otber green food, plus a considerable saving in the lighting charge, and other small items which will at once occur to those who have been compelled to "keep house" in the city itself. Of course the proposed bailding group or syndicate wonld not be expected to confine their energies to the amelioration of the lot of government officials only, but I have made a particular point of their case as the bousing problem, as I have indicated, has been a much debated question amongst them for years, while in the respective government depart ments and administrations the bon-technical employé can appeal to his professional and technical colleagues to belp him over his difficulties ; for example though I do not suggest that he should expect all services to be given gratuitously, be might have at his disposition the advice of civil, mechanical and sanitary engineers, architects and draughtsmen, agricultural and gardening experts and so on, at nominal fees. It has been suggested to me that there are quite enough companiesas it is, and the creation of another one is not desirable; true, but I do not suggest the creation of another company similar to some already existing ; far from it. The company I suggest is one that is actually wanted, is being asked for, and whieh ust come, for of six companies (two Rgyptian and four English with a combined capital of L.E. 1,500,000) one of whose objects as per their respective prospectuses is the construction of economical residences on the deferred payment or annuity system, not one is prepared to carry out this part of their programme except may be on lands belonging to themselves. Such being the case, no one of them may cavil at the formation of a group or company to aid small proprietors to build their own houses on their own lands, tor not one of them may be con-idered as an even very remotely possible client of any one of the existing companies. It is agreed op all sides that this housing problem is one calling for immediato attention, and as pointed out, none of the present ompanies are inclined, or in a position, to tackle the matter in the way it should be tackled, and although ove may be sorry for some of the shareholders, it is unreasonable to expect that they should monopolize whatever consideration and sympathy may be left when all of such consideration and sympathy should be extended to those who, ekeing out a precarious liveli. hood, are suffering, and so aoutely, as a consequence of the wild speculation and gambling in building land and house properties for which some company prospect uses are directly responsible Now Mr. Interested, I think you will have seen that the scheme I put forward is not so Utopian after all ; will you not "Come overand help us"?

div.head: WHITE SLAVE TRAFFIC
div.p: Mrs. Johnson, formerly of the Johnson, Home at Alexandria is addressing meetings in America of the Y.M.C.A. At a mass meeting recently beld in Chicago she declared that that city is the clearing house center of white slave traffic, which covers not only the United States, but which sells unfortunate girls, for export to Egypt.

FOOTBALL
ST. ANDREW F.C. v. DETACHMENT DUBLIN FUSILIERS.

The St. Andrew PC. on the 21st instant met a detachment of the Dublins at Mustapha Pasha. The Saints won the toss and elected to kick with the wind, which was blowing strongly. The visitors immediately pressed but in spite of the fact that they had for the first 20 minutes the most of the play they were not sacoesgful in scoring. On several oecasions tbe Dublins broke away but, thanks to the nseful work of Keill and Cassels at back, registered no points during the first half. At half time no goals were | scored. On resuming, the bome team kept the ball almost continuously in the Saints' territory, and ten minute: from time put the ball between the sticks froun a free kick near the mouth of the Saints' stronghold. Five minutes later the Saints were successful in forcing the ball through the Dublins' goal, but unfortunately the whistle had previously blowo for a foul against them. Cassels played a remarkably strong game | for St. Andrews and he and Keill composed a very reliable defence. Result. Dublins 1. St Andrews 0.

div.head: A RED SEA BIRD
div.p: One of the most interesting contributions to the London Zoo last week has been marle by the S.S. Pelamon," which on a voyage up the Red Pea was overtaken by a specimen of the somewhat rare Macqueen's Bustard. This birl's native place is in the sandly deserts of Egypt and Arabia ; it is not know tó migrate extensively, and is in no wise a sea-tow). The very likely explanation of its appearance so far from land is that it had been chased by one of the large falcons common on the Red Sea coasts, and in its flights bad flown out to gea, fearing to return until land had long been lost to sight, and the passing steamship became the only refuge for its tired wings.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Mardi 24 Decembre

Bien que l'ouverture ait eu lieu dans le même sens qu'hier il s'est produit à la suite de quelques aobats un relèvement partiel qui a rompa la monotonie des séances précédentes. Dans l'ensemble pourtant les offres ont continue poser sur les cours et à déterminer une nouvelle dépression. Parmi les valeurs qui ont joui d'un retour de faveur i faat signaler la National Bank en avance do 19 18/16 a 19 7/8, los Markets de 21/9 22/8, la Salt and Soda de 19/9 a 13/5 les Lots Turcs de 161 & 168, la Banque d'Orient de 111 1/4 a l'11/2, et l'Obligation nouvelle Crédit Poucier de 250 à 260 1/2. La Daira passe ici de 12 9,16 à 12 8/4 sans vendeurs, pendant qu'à Londres elle est demandée à 13. A noter snoore une reprise de la Sidi Salem qui, délaissée depuis quelque temps à 1 7/8, a donné liec ce matin a un certain mouvement aux environs de 2 livres. Ce réveil serait dû à la nouvelle que la Société aurait vendu en tout depuis sa constitution 625 feddans de ses ter. raing un prix moyen de 78 L.E. environ. Ona traité aussi l'Unifiée Egyptienne et la Khedivial Mail. La Delta Light a été recher chée. En revanche, ou a beaucaup offert l'Ur. haine et la Delta Land, qui ont fléchi pour ce motif la première de 3 116 à 2 7/8 et la seconde do 1 18111/6. Ea baisse également la Ramleh de 4 5/16 & 4 3/16, la Banque d Athènes de 112 1/4 & 112, les Nungovich Hotels de 14 34 à 14 1 2, l'Ordinary Khodivial Mail de 20/3 à 20/-, lo Comptoir de 2 3/16 4 2 1/8, la Building Lands de 1 7/16 à 1 3/8, l'Union Foncière de 4 5/16 à 41/4, la fondateur Allotment de 46 à 42 PT, et la Port Said Salt de 11/10 1/2 à 11 3. Il n'y a pas d'autre changement à signaler. Comme on le voit, l'ensemble continue à être déprimé. Le petite reprise partielle que nous venons de constater n'en est pas moins encou. rageante, si l'on pense que les ciroonstances sont plutôt défavorables. Elle est attribuée à des achats de portefeuilles qui estiment avan. tageux les cours atteints par les valeurs en question. Le fait est que précisément à cause du bas niveau actuel, les détenteurs ne vendent plus qu'à la dernière extrémité. C'est ce qui explique le fléchissement inogi de l'Obligation Crédit Foncier 274 vendeurs. Ce titre étant toujours négociable et répandu parmi la petite épargne, celle-ci le liquide pour se faire du numéraire pour ses écbéances de fin d'année. On critique beancoup la vente aux enchères publiques faite au Caire par une banque de la ville. Paute de publicité donnée à cette vente le paquet a été écoulé à des prix très bas, Le taux privé d'escompte en Angleterre, qui avait haussé bier de 6 à 6 1/8 est revenu à 6. En raison de la fermeture de la corbeille des valeurs demain et après-demain à l'occasion de la fête de Noël notre prochain bulletin ne paraltra que vendredi, 27 courant.

Il est porté à la connaissance des action naires des "United Hotels of Egypt Ltd." que conformément à l'article 67 des "articles of Association", vu que le quorum n'a pas été atteint à l'assemblée Générale Extraordinaire réunie le Lundi, 23 Décembre 1907 à 4 heures p.m. au siège dela Société sis 21 rue Emad Elbine, le Caire, la dite Assemblée est ajournée au Lundi 30 Décembre 1907, aux mêmes lieu et beure. Le Caire le 23 Décembre 1907.
Par ordre du Conseil N. MORRISON Secrétaire en Egypte.

div.p: NOTICE.

The Sudan Medical Department is in need of the services of a qualified dispenser with pay commencing £16 per mensem Applications for this post will be addres. sed to the Director Sudan Medical Department, Khartoum They should be accompanied with all oertificates, tertimonials, references, etc., and with a duly filled up. Application form which is obtainable (togetber with any intormation as to pay, increase of pay, con ditions of service, etc.,) from the Sadan Agency, War Office, Cairo. A good knowledge of English and Arabic (reading and writing) is indispensable. The chosen candidate will be taken oh probation for a period of two years.

div.head: Khedival Mail Steamship and Graving Dook Company, Limited.
div.p: Notice is hereby given that at tbe Annual General Meeting of this Company held in London on the 9th December 1907, it was decided to pay a dividend of 10 per cent on the Ordinary Sbares for the year ending 30th June 1907. Holders of Share Warrants to bearer will be paid their dividend at the rate of 2/- per share, less income tax, against presentation of Conpon No. 5 on and after the 31st December 1907 at the Imperial Ottoman Bank, Alex andria, or at Messrs. Glyn, Mills, Currie & Co. Lombard Street, London, E.C. Registered Holders of Ordinary Shares will receive their Divideod Warrants by post. Alexandria 20th December 1907.

div.head: UNION DRAGOMANS' SOCIETY
div.p: HARET EL ZAHAR
(OPPOSITE SHEPHEARD's HOTEL) OR Box No.9 P.O. Telegraphic address "Union Dragomans."
NOTICE TO TOURISTS.

We beg to inform all Ladies and Gentlemen Tourists that after having taken in serious consideration the latest comments on the behaviour of Dragomans, we have formed the above Society for the safety and satisfaction of our patrons. Our Society is composed of the best known respectable Dragomans, Guides and Couriers, well acquainted with the business, the necessary languages, the ways, the history of ruined monuments, not only of Egypt but as well of Holy Land, Greece, Turkey and Europe. Contracts can be made for the Nile, Camping in the Desert, to Holy Land, Greece, Turkey and Europe.
WARNING!!!

All members of our union bear a permit from the Government given to them after a strict examination on their ability and good behaviour, see that your Dragoman produces to you with the said permit, a card of Membership of our Union, and to avoid trouble and confusion have the right man to meet you on your disembarkation. Each member of this union whose name is in the paper is entitled to wear a button on his jacket with the Initials (U.D.S)
CABLE "DRAGUNION" CAIRO
NAMES

T.MK Moses, Said Aly, Ahmed Aly, A. Bernard, Salim Onahluf, Moustafa Gad, Geor ge Gattas, Saleh Hainzah, Alexander K. The Great, Mohamed Aly Hassan, Mourad Habbouba, Sady Amar, K. Ibrahim, Tadros Mi. chel, Mobamed Aly Salah, Hassan Mohamed, Ahmed Hussein Sakr, Mobamed Ahmed, Ibrahim Abdalla, Charles Chaia.

div.head: Vente de Materiel Flottant a Vapour
div.p: La Compagnie Universelle du Canal Ma ritime de Suez met en vente les 4 remorqueurs ci-après:
"VIGOUREUX" -- remorqueur de mer, à une hélice - de 220 Chevaux.
"108" remorqueur de service intérieur, & 2 bélices de 70 Chevaux environ;
"112" et "113"- remorqueurs de service in térieur, à 1 helice de 90 Chev, environ.

Les offres d'achat seront reçues par M. l'Ingénieur en Chef de la Compagnie à Ismailia jusqu'au 20 Février 1908. Pour tous renseignements s'adresser aux bureaux du Service de l'Entretien de la Compagnie, à Port-Said, Ismailia ou Suez.

div.head: Societe Internationale des Employes D'ALEXANDRIE.
div.p: D'ALEXANDRIE. SIEGE SOCIAL RUN SIDI KL METWALLI No. 80 m Rue HAMKAN KL ZAHAB No. 1 au 1B Brage
BUREAU DE PLACEMENT
5. - Comptable correspondant accepterait place aux villages ou au Caire.
6. – Ancien employé de magasins de confec tion cherche place. Très bonnes références.
7 - Aide-comptable d'agence de Bourse cberche place.
9. - Jeune homme, bonnête et actif, connais sant bien le français et l'italien, 19 ans, cherche emploi.
10.- Jeune homme, 40 ans, initié au commerce, honnête et actif, connaissant l'italien et le français et on peu l'allemand cherche emploi.
12.- Professeur de français cherche leçons.
13.-Ancien chef de rayon d'ameublements dans une grande maison d'Europe chercbe même situation en Egypte. Il parle et écrit quatre langues.
16.--Monsieur connaissant parfaitement bien l'anglais et parlant 8 autres langues cherche des leçons d'anglais ou un emploi dans un bureau.
17.- Professeur d'anglais cherche des leçons.
18.-On demande au Caire un employé chez | un armurier.
19.-On demande une apprentie couturière et une très borme ouvrière couturière. S'adresser chez Mme Mollet 15 rue Nabi Daniel de 11 h. a.m. à 12 1/2.
20.-Un anglais disposant de ses après-midis cherche oocupation dans un bureau ou des leçons.

21. - Ancien employé de Maison de change cbercbe travail dans un bureau et s'offre à faire des encaissements à la commission pour compte de tiers. Il est muni de certificats attestant son bonnêteté et son intelligence. Il parle et écrit le français et l'arabe.

22 - Un homme très recommandé par un Monsieur honorable et connaissant bien le français, le grec, l'italien et la comptabilité cherche emploi dans un bureau ou magasin. Il accepterait la place de surveillant de constructions

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette. "
div.p: The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt for abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For Further particulars apply to the Manager the "Egyptian Gazette."

div.head: Egyptian State Railways.
div.p: NOTICE.
SALE OF COTTON AND COTTON SEED BY PUBLIC AUCTION AT GABBARY STATION

The Administration has the honour to inform the Public that on Monday, 30th December, 1907, and following days, if necessary, at 3 p.m., there will be put up to auction at Gabbary Station (Inward Stores), under the following conditions, about 55 TONS OF COTTON AND 268 TONS OF COTTON SEED:

1. No one will be admitted to the auction unless be pays in advance the sum of FIFTY EGYPTIAN POUNDS (in Cash, Egyptian Bonds or other values accepted by the Administration) as a deposit. This deposit will bear no interest but is to serve as a guarantee for the Administration and to ensure the execution of the following clauses, and can, if necessary, be deducted from the price of an article purchased at the auction. The deposit should be personal and in the name of the depositor acting on his own account.
2. Bidders should examine the condition, quantity and quality of the goods put up for auction before remitting the deposit.
3. The fact of competing at the auction involves acceptance on the part of the bidder of the condition, quality, etc. of the goods, and no claim relating thereto will be accepted.
4. Once the tender is accepted, the bidder must -
(a) Pay in at once and in full the price, deduction being made of his deposit

(b) Withdraw, after payment, at his own expense and risk, the goods purchased as soon as the price has been paid in (packing being in his charge) but, in any case, the goods will be at his own risk from the moment the tender is accepted.

5. In case of refusal on the part of the bidder to pay the full price, or to withdraw the articles purchased, within 24 hours at the latest, the Administration will have the right to put up the goods to auction again at the bidder's risk. In case, however, & higher price is offered, the first offer will be definitely forfeited.
6. The Administration reserves the right -
(a) Of selling the goods in one or more lots ;
(b) Of renouncing the sale after the opening of the auction but before the tender is accepted ;
(c) of treating amicably for part or all the goods ;
(d) Of adjudging the sale to a person other than the last and highest bidder.
In any case, the bidder will have the right to the refund of his deposit, but without interest or any indemnity whatever.

div.head: Municipalite d'Alexandrie
div.p: AVIS

La Municipalité met en adjudication la fourniture des Gargouilles et Sabots nécessaires à son service. Le cautionnement est fixé L.E. 30 (trente.) Le cahier des charges est déposau bureau Technique où il peut être consulte par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h à midi, les jours fériés exceptés. Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté a Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 7 Janvier 1908. Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5 h. p.m. L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la men tion: "Soumission pour fourniture Gargouilles et Sabots." Le cautionnement ou le recu d'une banque d'après les conditions du cabier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avait l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 7 Janvier 1908 à midi. Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
Alexandrie, le 20 Décembre 1907.
L'Administrateur (Signe), W.P CHATAWAY.
AVIS

La Municipalité met en adjudication la fourniture des articles nécessaires Aix rouleaux compresseurs pendaut l'année 1908 Le cautionnement est fixé à L. Eg 25 vingt cinq.) Le cahier des charges est déposé au bureau Techuique ou il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9h à inidi, les jours fériés exceptés. Les offres devront être adressées 8008 pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 31 Décembre 1907. Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5h. p m. L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la men tion "Soumission por Fourniture Articles pour rouleaux compresseurs." Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque d'après les conditions du cahier des charges devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 31 décembre midi. Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera cartée
Alexandrie, le 9 Décembre 1907.
L'Administrateur (Signe) W.P. CHATAWAY

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life.
